bindep.txt.message:
I guess this was added with I6b51565a81cb7d47bb971505570431ba784ec26b but it's not exactly clear why.  

What exactly about the "test" profile requires python 3.8?  

while i agree we run tox-py38 and with the recent change I346c2fe22f8409c600a3ee2a229369778e3cabd6 we install that into the images, that seems to be more that we are running those environments under 3.8, rather than the test profile *requires* 3.8

In other words, I don't see anything in the zuul code-base that requires python3.8 to run tests.

ergo, can we just remove this?

The platform:ubuntu-bionic specifier is the hint to what this was created for. I believe it is an artifact of running unittests on bionic which doesn't have python3.7 installed by default (it has 3.6). It also doesn't have 3.8 either, but our jobs now specify the python versions themselves and handle that for us (https://zuul.opendev.org/t/zuul/build/f168c9fb53544a839f0253272c60a6be/console#2/0/1/ubuntu-bionic shows this).

Finally, our docker images are debian based so won't match these lines anyway.

All that to say: yes I think we can remove these two lines.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message:
There's a builtin function for this, we do not need to iterate:

external_ids.update(ovn_port.external_ids)
That is right. We do not want to simply overwrite the dict with potentially old values. We just want to add key/value pairs that were not created/modified by the update.
I *think* the difference between this and update() is update will update things that already exist in the dict, whereas this will only add items that aren't there.

modules/openstack_project/manifests/ask..message:
This sets up a refresh notification from copy-solr to the file resource but file resources don't understand refreshes (see https://docs.puppetlabs.com/puppet/latest/reference/lang_relationships.html#refreshing).

Maybe a simpler fix would be to copy the files to a place where they will not be deleted? Perhaps we can put them in /opt

Also I've tested this and it doesn't seem to help. I still get:

Error: /Stage[main]/Openstack_project::Ask/File[/usr/share/solr/WEB-INF/lib/lucene-analyzers-smartcn-4.7.2.jar]: Could not evaluate: Could not retrieve information from environment fungi source(s) file:/tmp/solr-4.7.2/contrib/analysis-extras/lucene-libs/lucene-analyzers-smartcn-4.7.2.jar

I've hunted through the vamsee/puppet-solr source, as well as our puppet-askbot and system-config repos. It's not apparent to me what creates  or is supposed to create the /tmp/solr-4.7.2/contrib/analysis-extras/lucene-libs/lucene-analyzers-smartcn-4.7.2.jar file. The server has no /tmp/solr-.* directories at all.
Agree with clark. Any kind of /tmp and tarball-extraction stuff with puppet breaks the model and gets weird pretty fast. Putting it into a known location in opt is a good call.

Oh, wait, I think I see the intent now. There _is_ already a /usr/share/solr/WEB-INF/lib/lucene-analyzers-smartcn-4.7.2.jar file on the server. What you're trying to do is only fire the copy from /tmp/ if the destination file is not already present, and puppet is insisting on making sure the source file is present too even though the process which created that file (as part of a puppet module we don't control) ran long before and the tmpreaper on the server has since deleted it?

Yeah guys, but not this module extracts the .tar.gz into tmp. It happens in an external puppet module, vamsee-solr. I made a solr module before, and it was working perfectly for our use-case, but it was voted down.

So changing that file resource into an Exec is acceptable compromise here? I can add the required tests for file existence, and it is invoked after successful copy-solr execution.

> I used 'feature' for the release mainly because for all the

 > 12.4 .5 .6.0 ... 

No problem

 > 
 > hmmm perhaps it makes more sense to use 'bugfix' * but then why not
 > for all of these why just os-net-config in particular.

No, you can leave as it is, everything LGTM, I was more thinking out loud :) it seems to me that other tripleo's  projects are legit to deliver a minor version. Different supports have been added so a minor version is fine for them.

 > 
 > 
 > * to be clear that would bump the .patch in maj.min.patch right?

To answer your question, yes that would bump the Z in X.Y.Z, but please feel free to leave as it is :)

Below are some more details about this, just for an explanation purpose.

Consider X.Y.Z:
- a major version will raise the X, it would be triggered by changes who drop the backward compatibility;
- a minor version will raise the Y, it would be triggered by changes who introduce a new feature, a requirements who have been bumped;
- a bugfix version will raise the Z, it would be triggered by changes who fix something.

With the changes in test-requirements (and testing requirements in general) minor and bugfix version can be used as this kind of requirements are not really used during the runtime and at the execution of the deliverable and so they don't impact the stability or the behavior of the deliverable during runtime. However these requirements can be bumped too and normally it should be reflected by a minor version by a strict semver. This is why we are in a grey area in this case.

Because it is better to read it of the resource, i.e the truth. Allowing the users to accidentally type the wrong value in non-validated heat parameters has proven unwise in the past. (NOTE, I started something https://review.opendev.org/752922 to make the network/subnet attributes available to set GroupVars by role correctly here. If we merged CtlplaneNetworkAttrs into the net_attributes_map we would get the complete picture. And in the future the ansible module to populate the "deployed-network-environment" can do the work: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/751739/2/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_network_populate_environment.py

The reference to thread_name in sdk_platform.py is only under condition 'if region_clients:'.   The thread_name is used in the construction of the cached_region_clients_for thread.  Thus, if region_clients is None, it does not reference the thread_name.

Thread_name is only relevant if region_clients is not None (see sdk_platform.py). In the add subcloud/delete subcloud context, the only relevant region is RegionOne.
